titleInfo.title: Sextus Iulius Frontinus uir consularis De re militari. Flauius Vegetius uir illustris De re militari. Aelianus De instruendis aciebus. Modesti Libellus de uocabulis rei militaris
Ad Valentinianum Augustum epitoma institutorum rei militaris

originInfo.publisher: Impressit omni solertia Plato de Benedictis Bononiensis in alma ciuitate Bononiae

mods.note: Edited by Joannes Sulpitius Verulanus and Filippo Beroaldo. The authors collected here are from those traditionally known as Scriptores rei militaris.

Frontinus' work is known as Stratagematica; Vegetius' work is commonly titled De re militari; Aelianus' work, written in Greek, is known by the Latin title Tactica; the De vocabulis rei militaris, passing under the name of one Modestus, is believed to have been copied from Vegetius in the 15th cent.
In 4 pts., each one dated: I) 10 July 1495; II) 16 Nov. 1495; III) [n.d.]; IV: [n.d.]; place of publication and publisher statement from general colophon (leaf 2R5v), which is dated: 17 Jan. 1496.
Diagrams of military tactical formations are created by the use of ordinary printer's types arranged in patterns showing the positioning of troops.

titleInfo.title: Here begynneth the lyf of saint katherin of senis the blessid virgin
Vita di S. Catarina da Siena
Item of the synguler maner of lyuinge
Item of the synguler maner of lyvinge
Vita di S. Catarina da Siena. English

mods.note: A translation of a Latin version of: Raymond of Capua. Vita di S. Catarina da Siena.
Printer's name from colophon; publication date conjectured by STC.
Secundo folio: Item of the synguler maner of lyuinge ..

"Here beginnen the reuelacio[n]s of Saynt Elysabeth the kynges doughter of hungarye,", caption title, p5v. It is a translation of the "Revelationes Sanctae Elizabethae Hungariae", sometimes attributed to Saint Elizabeth of Hungary or to Elizabeth of Toess, and misattributed to Jacobus Montanus (see Halkett & Laing (3rd ed., 1980), p. 94 and "The Library" 14 (March 1992), p. 1-11).
Colophon begins "Here enden the reuelacions of saynt Elysabeth the kynges doughter of hungarye ..". For a later issue see STC 24766.3.
Identified as STC 24768 in UMI microfilm reel guide.

titleInfo.title: Hec sunt rubrice quaternionu[m] Flosculoru[m] & Transitus Sancti Hyeronimi doctoris eximii & Miraculoru[m] & quaru[n]dam Ep[isto]larum Sancti Augustini de laudibus Sancti Hyeronimi ad Cyrilum Ep[iscopu]m Yponensem & Cyrilii ad Augustinum
Aureola ex floribus S. Hieronymi contexta
Regula monachorum ex Epistolis Hieronymi excerpta

originInfo.publisher: Imp[re]ssum p[er] magistru[m] Philippum de Lauagnia i.cccc.lxxv. [i.e. 1475] die xxviii Noue[m]br.

mods.note: Title from end of register (recto of last leaf).

The Aureola is the work elsewhere attributed to Lupus de Oliveto (or Olmeto) with title Regula monachorum ex Epistolis Hieronymi excerpta. Cf. B. Lambert, Bibliotheca Hieronymiana manuscripta, IIIb (Steenbrugis, 1970) no. 552; Sack, V. Freiburg, 2294. The 'editorship' of Thomas Dorniberg seems to apply only to the Speyer edition, where Dorniberg states that this selection from Jerome's writings was made by an anonymous compiler (cf. BM 15th cent., II p. 482).
Includes Vita et transitus Hieronymi (i.e. Eusebius of Cremona's Epistola de morte Hieronymi), St. Augustine's Epistola de magnificentiis Hieronymi, and St. Cyril's De miraculis Hieronymi.
Imprint from colophon (leaf [y]8r); Filippo da Lavagna was active in Milan.

Dimensions of the printed p. (a2r): 41 lines, 155 x 93 mm. (signatures printed at end of the last line of text); dimensions of the leaf: 194 x 130 mm.
Types correspond apparently to the description of 75 G (text) and 185 G (t.p.) as outlined in BM 15th cent., VIII, p. 201-202 (plate XXVIII).
Goff P-592 wrongly given as: "208ff., about 1492"; Folger copy matches BM copy with 232 leaves.
Device of AndreÌ� Bocard on t.p.; device of FeÌ�lix Baligault on verso of last leaf; for date of publication, see BM 15th cent.
Capital spaces, most of them with guide letters.

titleInfo.title: Platinae historici Liber de uita Christi, ac Pontificum omnium, qui hactenus ducenti et uigintiduo fuere
Liber de vita Christi, ac Pontificvm omnivm, qui hactenvs dvcenti et vigintidvo fvere

mods.note: Leaf a1v reads: Proemivm Platynae in Vitas Pontificvm ad Sixtvm. IIII. Pontificem Maximum.
Probably a reprint from the edition of De Colonia and Manthen, Venice, 1479, with the omission of the letter of Squarzaficus to the author and of "impressum" in the colophon.--Brit. Mus.
This book, which shows no internal connexion with Treviso, may be Venetian and date from 1485-86. The watermark of a crescent was in use in both Treviso and Venice about this time.--Brit. Mus.

titleInfo.title: Preclarissimus liber elementorum Euclidis perspicacissimi, in artem geometrie incipit qua[m]foelicissime

originInfo.publisher: Erhardus Ratdolt Augustensis impressor solertissimus Venetijs impressit
originInfo.dateIssued: anno Salutis 1482 octauis Calen[darum] Iun[ij] [25 May]

physicalDescription.extent: [276] p. (the last [2] p. blank) : ill. (woodcuts) ; 30 cm. (fol.)

mods.note: Title from incipit in red (leaf a2r).
Also published on vellum and illuminated. Variations in the incipit, dedication, headlines in the first signature, etc. are recorded, issued with the same colophon.

Translated from Arabic by Adelard of Bath; edited by Campano da Novara. While books I-XIII are Euclid's (cf. Th. Heath. The thirteen books of Euclid's Elements. 1956, v.3, p. 519), Book XIV is a work of the 2d cent. by Hypsicles and book XV the work of a Roman land-surveyor of the 6th century. For a discussion by B.L. van der Waerden of Euclid's sources see Enc. Brit., 15th ed., Micro. IV, p 589.
With dedicatory letter by Erhard Ratdolt.

Imprint from colophon (leaf r7v), which reads: Opus elementoruÌƒ euclidis megarensis in geometriaÌƒ arteÌƒ. In id quoqz Campani p[er]spicacissimi CoÌƒmentationes finiuÌƒt. Erhardus ratdolt Augustensis impressor solertissimus. venetijs impressit. Anno salutis M.cccc.lxxxii. Octauis. CalenÌƒ. JunÌƒ. Lector. Vale.
Woodcut initials, large and small, and diagrams in margins throughout; woodcut three-sided border on leaf a2r.
Headlines: book numbers throughout, Liber I-Liber XV.
Liber III, Propositio 18 (leaf c1r) reads: Si circuluÌƒ linea recta coÌƒtingat: ...

titleInfo.title: descrypcyon of Englonde
titleInfo.subTitle: Here foloweth a lytell treatyse the whiche treateth of the descrypcyon of this londe whiche of olde tyme was named Albyon and after Brytayne and now is called Englonde and speketh of the noblenesse and worthynesse of the same

mods.note: Imprint from colophon, which reads: Here endeth the descrypcyon of Brytayne .. therfore I haue sette the desrypcyon [sic] of the same after the sayd Brytayne, whiche I haue taken out of Polycronycon. And by cause it is necessarye to all Englysshmen to knowe the propretees co[m]modytees and meruaylles of them, therfore I William Caxton haue them sette fyrste in enprynte accordynge to the translac[i]on of Treuisa, whiche atte request of the lorde Barkeley translated the boke of Polycronycon in to Englysshe. Fynysshed and enprynted at Westmestre by me Wynken de worde, the yere of our lorde a. M.CCCC. and foure score and .xviij.
Generally considered pt. II of Saint Albans chronicle, STC 9996.

titleInfo.title: Prohemye grete thankynges lawde and honoure we merytoryously ben bounde to yelde and offre vnto wryters of hystoryes
Grete thankynges lawde and honoure we merytoryously ben bounde to yelde and offre unto wryters of hystoryes
Syth the tyme that the grete and high tonr of babilone was bylded

mods.note: By Ranulf Higden. An English translation by John Trevisa. Edited and with a continuation by William Caxton. All three individuals are named on a3v.
Caxton's continuation is reprinted from "The chronicles of England", STC 9991.

Colophon (referring to the preparation of the text) reads: ... ended the second day of Iuyll the xxij yere of the regne of kynge Edwardthe [sic] fourth [and] of the Incarnacion of oure lord a thousand four honderd foure score and tweyne, fynysshed per Caxton.

Opening of text, a2r: "Prohemye gRete thankynges lawde [and] honoure we merytoryously ben bounde to yelde and offre vnto wryters of hystoryes ..."; "1"2r: "sYth the tyme that the grete and high tonr [sic] of babilone was bylded ...".
The first leaf and the last leaf are blank.

Prologue, 2A2r, begins: Here foloweth the right deuoute, moche lowable, [and] reco[m]mendable lyff of the olde auncyent holy faders hermytes, late translated out of latyn in to frenshe, and dylygently corrected in the cyte of lyon, ye yere of our lord. M.CCCC.lxxxvi. vpon that whiche hath be wryten and also translated out of Greke in to Latyn, by the blessyd [and] holy saynt Saynt Ierome .. [and] other solytarye relygyouse persones after hy[m] and after in the yere of our lorde .M.CCCC.lxxxxi. reduced in to Englysshe ..
There are variants of 2A1, q2.7, and the colophon. "One L copy has some leaves reprinted c. 1529 w. a woodcut of about that date"--STC.

titleInfo.title: Here begynneth the legende named in Latyn Legenda aurea, that is to say in Englyshe the Golden legende

name.namePart: Mildmay, Henry Bouverie Paulet St. John

physicalDescription.extent: [4], xli, xl-CClix, CClxi-CCCxl, CCCxl-CCCCxxix leaves : ill. (woodcuts) ; 29 cm. (fol.)

mods.note: A translation, probably by William Caxton, based in part on the French translation of Jacobus de Voragine.
"This is the only ed. to omit the stories from the Bible"--STC.

Colophon reads: Thus endeth the lege[n]de named in latyn Legenda aurea .. whiche werke I dyde accomplisshed [sic] at the commaundeme[n]te and requeste of the noble and puyssaunte Erle [and] my specyal good Lord Wyllyam Erle of Arondel, And now hane [sic] renewed [and] fynysshed it at Westmestre the xx day of May, The yere of our Lord MCCCClxxxxiii, And in the viii yere of the reygne off Kynge Henry the vii, by me Wyllyam Caxton.

titleInfo.subTitle: whiche booke hath ben translated in to Englysshe by Mayster Benet Burgh, late Archedeken of Colchestre and hye chanon of Saint Stephens at Westmestre ... and by cause of late cam to my hand a book of the said Caton in Frensshe, whiche reherceth many a fayr lernynge and notable ensamples, I haue translated it oute of Frensshe in to Englysshe, as al along here after shalle appiere, whiche I presente vnto the cyte of London

mods.note: The original Latin text of the Disticha, with an anonymous prose paraphrase and commentary.
The disticha, wrongly attributed to Marcus Porcius Cato, in fact date from imperial times.
Printer's name from STC; publication date from Needham.

Includes: Bucolica, Georgica, Aeneis with argumenta (commentary by Servius). De Hortulus. De vino et Venere. De livore. De cantu Sirenarum. De die natali. De fortuna. De Orpheo. De se ipso. De aetatibus animalium. De ludo. De aerumnis Herculis. De Musarum inventis. Elegia in Maecenatis obitu. De speculo. Mira Vergilii versus experientia. Mira Vergilii experientia. De quattuor temporibus anni. De ortu solis. De Herculis laboribus. De littera Y. De signis caelestibus. Priapea. Copa. Est et non. Vir bonus. Rosae. Culex. Dirae. Aetna. Ciris. Catalecton. Moretum. Donatus: Vita Vergilii. Ovidius: Versus. Alcimus: Versus de Vergilio. Cornelius Gallus: Versus de Aeneide. Epitaphia virorum illustrium. Summa Vergilianae narrationis.

Imprint from colophon (leaf [2c]9r); on the date, which reads M.CCCC.LXXY in most copies, but also M.CCCC.LXXX (see R 357), see D.E. Rhodes, in The Library, 5th ser., 30 (1975), p. 189. For variants, cf. also BN incun.

titleInfo.title: In hoc uolumine sunt Tractatus siue epistole numero centum et uiginti una non omnes tame[n] Sancti Hieronymi

originInfo.dateIssued: anno Christi 1468 indictione prima, die uero xiii. mensis Decembris

mods.note: This fragment is identifiable as the 1468 rather than 1470 ed. because the headings are not printed, but rather left to the rubricator.

Type corresponds to 115R, employed by Sweynheim and Pannartz at Rome, as described in BM 15th cent., IV, p. 4. It is not the 115R used by Arnold Pannartz for his 1476 first pt. of the Epistolae, which is distinguishable from the earlier type by a different "a", and the addition of "eÌʹ", alternative "i" (dotted), and of final "s" of the usual rounded kind (Cf. BM 15th cent., IV, p. 60). These characteristics are not present; moreover, the "r" has the straight shank without serif at base which did not change until the middle of 1470.

titleInfo.title: Aurelii Augustini Hipponen[sis] Episcopi De ciuitate Dei primi libri incipiunt rubrice

mods.note: Title from incipit of table (leaf [*]2r); imprint from colophon (leaf [G]8r), which reads: ... CoÌƒradus suueynheym: Arnoldus paÌƒnartzq; magistri Rome impresserunt talia multa simul ... M.CCCCLXX.
Printed in a single column; capital spaces.

"Augustinus De ciuitate Dei is the first item of Schedel's list, a position which suggests that a remainder of the 1468 ed. is there referred to rather than the present ed. On the other hand, the price (5 ducats) suits a book of 294 leaves better than one of 274 leaves, and as it has the early form of "r," it must belong to the early part of 1470 and is thus presumably early enough to be included in the list"--BM 15 cent., IV, p. 11.
